items.abstract:
<jats:p>

Although the presence of metabotropic glutamate (mGlu) receptors in the central nervous system is well documented, they have recently been found in peripheral and non-neuronal tissues. In the present study we investigated the expression of group III mGlu receptors in the reproductive system of male mice. Reverse transcription–polymerase chain reaction analysis revealed the presence of mGlu6, mGlu7 and mGlu8 (but not mGlu4) receptor transcripts in testes and epididymides from adult mice. In addition, expression of mGlu6 (Grm6) and mGlu8 receptor (Grm8) mRNA was detected in spermatozoa isolated from the vas deferens. The vas deferens was found to contain only mGlu7 receptor (Grm7) mRNA, which was particularly intense in 21-day-old male mice. In penile homogenates, only the mGlu7 receptor signal was detected. Genetic ablation of the mGlu7 receptor in males led to fertility disorders manifested by decreased insemination capability as well as deterioration of sperm parameters, particularly sperm motility, vitality, sperm membrane integrity and morphology, with a simultaneous increase in sperm concentration. These results indicate that constitutively expressed mGlu receptors in the male reproductive system may play an important role in ejaculation and/or erection processes, as well as in the formation and maturation of spermatozoa.
</jats:p>
title: Expression of group III metabotropic glutamate receptors in the reproductive system of male mice

reference.unstructured: This was the case for many reasons: the French conception of property law makes it normally impossible for two persons or legal entities to have ownership rights over the same asset in the way that the trust allows. This is because French law considers that a good can only be owned by one person (s 544 of the French Civil Code), whereas the concept of the trust permits the idea of equitable ownership and legal ownership, thus allowing two owners of the same good. On top of this, the French revenue service has always been very wary of the concept of the trust, considering that it poses a tax-evasion risk.
PK Agboyibor and P Tallot, “Securitisation in France: From a Renewed Legislation to an Expanding Marketplace”, 3, available at http://www.orrick.com/fileupload/783.pdf.

This is supposed to prevent the FCC from being a taxable entity under French Corporate Income Tax which would mean that the profits made through the securitisation would be taxed at the FCC's level and at the shareholders' level.

This rule has been set to avoid companies or banks having control of a management company which would be in charge of an FCC that would purchase its own receivables. In such a scheme, the originator controls the company that manages the FCC that just purchased its receivables. This would pose great problems in terms of accounting considering that securitisation is often pursued to make the receivables leave the originator's balance sheet.
This situation is allowed by s L 214–48(II) of the CMF and happens in most cases when the originator is a financial institution.

reference.unstructured: For a detailed study of the French securitisation regime before this reform in comparison with the English regime, see the author's article published in this review: F Burnat, “Titrisation v securitisation: a legal comparison of securitisation in France and the United Kingdom” (2008) 2 LFMR 143.
The 2008 Ordinance is not retroactive which implies that old FCCs can carry out their activities under the old regime or decide to be transformed into FCTs. S L 214–49–14 of the CMF.

In this respect, it is interesting to note that the CMF does not describe the corporate governance of securitisation companies. Whereas it is pretty clear that FCTs are only managed by their management company (since they have no legal personality), securitisation companies on the contrary have corporate bodies which in a regular company would manage the activities of the said company. These bodies face the competition of the management company which pursuant to S L 214–49–1 is in charge of managing the securitisation company. F Faure-Dauphin, “La société de titrisation” (2008) 3 Revue trimestrielle de droit financier 87.
Although the tax authorities have not yet issued any guide lines on the tax regime of these securitisation companies.

funder.name: Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education

items.abstract: <jats:p>The paper presents a concept of lifelong plasticity of peripheral vision. Central vision processing is accepted as critical and irreplaceable for normal perception in humans. While peripheral processing chiefly carries information about motion stimuli features and redirects foveal attention to new objects, it can also take over functions typical for central vision. Here I review the data showing the plasticity of peripheral vision found in functional, developmental, and comparative studies. Even though it is well established that afferent projections from central and peripheral retinal regions are not established simultaneously during early postnatal life, central vision is commonly used as a general model of development of the visual system. Based on clinical studies and visually deprived animal models, I describe how central and peripheral visual field representations separately rely on early visual experience. Peripheral visual processing (motion) is more affected by binocular visual deprivation than central visual processing (spatial resolution). In addition, our own experimental findings show the possible recruitment of coarse peripheral vision for fine spatial analysis. Accordingly, I hypothesize that the balance between central and peripheral visual processing, established in the course of development, is susceptible to plastic adaptations during the entire life span, with peripheral vision capable of taking over central processing.</jats:p>
title: Are Visual Peripheries Forever Young?
